p: Among isolates, the saturation level K ranged from 79% to 100% (mean ± SD: 93 ± 7%). The slope factor B was transformed into Δt, the time required to rise from 10% to 90% of the saturation level, which ranged from 1.85 to 7.73 days (mean ± SD: 4.37 ± 2.03 days). The lag time M ranged from 4.84 to 7.36 days (mean ± SD: 5.68 ± 0.82 days). There was no statistically significant correlation between the three parameters ( S2 Fig). However, isolates with a high saturation level tended to display a large slope factor and a short lag time. To graphically represent EIP variation among DENV isolates, we used the distribution of lag time ( M) values as a proxy. We obtained the daily rate of new systemic infections by calculating the first derivative of the cumulative systemic infection function ( Fig 2B). The curve of this rate over time is equivalent to the distribution of lag time values among individual mosquitoes.
